section.title: Comparative and superlative adjectives
section.sectiontitle: We use the comparative to compare two things and the superlative to compare more than two things.
section.sectiontitle2: With one-syllable adjectives, we make the comparative and superlative with adjective + -r/-er/-ier or the + adjective + -st/-est/-iest.
section.text3a: I'm taller than Sam but Will's the tallest in the class.
section.text4a: Osaka is larger than Kyoto but Tokyo is the largest and busiest city in Japan.

section.title: Comparative and superlative adjectives
section.sectiontitle: With most two-syllable adjectives and longer adjectives, we use more + adjective or the most + adjective.
section.text2a: The Ferrari's the most powerful car of all.
section.sectiontitle2: Some adjectives are irregular: <i>good, better, the best; bad, worse, the worst; far, further, the furthest.
section.text4a: The station is further from here than the cinema.

section.title: Other comparative and superlative forms
section.sectiontitle: We use more and the most to compare nouns.
section.text2a: Keith's got the most students in his class.
section.sectiontitle2: We use also similar to, the same as, different from, look like to compare things and people.
